Q: Your newest book, "Necessary Illusions" is 
subtitled "Thought Control in Democratic Societies".

How can there be thought control in a democratic 
society such as the United States? Isn't that a

contradiction? Well, it depends what you mean 
by democracy. If you mean by democracy that

ordinary people should have a, play a meaningful 
role in controlling public affairs and determining

decisions about how the system works and 
so on, yeah, it's a total contradiction .

But the point is that elite elements, privileged 
elite elements, have never meant that by democracy.

They've always regarded democracy as a threat 
which has to be contained and controlled and

this goes way back to the first democratic 
revolutions in the 17th century in England.

As soon as it became clear that you're going 
to lose the, you know, that would no longer be

possible to control people by force it immediately 
followed as an almost as a corollary that you're

going to have to control what they think. If you 
have a what we nowadays call a totalitarian state

or a military-run state or whatever you really 
don't care much about what people think, they can think

anything they feel like, because you can control 
them with a bludgeon. But as the state loses

its capacity to coerce through threats or 
terror or just one or another form of force, then

other means have to be found to 
ensure that democracy doesn't work,

that the democratic forms in other words 
persist but without interfering with the

right of the privileged uh elements to rule. Now,
you know, what the privileged elements are may

differ in different societies. In modern capitalist 
democracies the privileged sectors are those who

own, are the corporate elite basically, they own 
the country more or less, in fact, more not less.

They effectively own the country and  
they basically control the political system.

In the United States this is really a one-party 
state, it's a business party with two factions,

and they control the media, the ideological system, 
and they impose very sharp constraints on any form

of policy. any policy that's formulated even 
even if the political system ever got out of

their control which is unlikely, it couldn't 
get very far out, because the weapons of

capital strike and disinvestment and reduction of 
business confidence and so on are sufficient to

control policy. So there's lots of mechanisms that 
ensure that those who own the country govern it

And we should bear in mind that that was the 
principle of the founding fathers that those

who own the country ought to govern it. That's 
in fact a quote from John Jay, the president of

the constitutional convention. That's the way the 
country's founded, now the problem is how do

you deal with all of this when people are free 
as they are like the state they can't send in

the police to break up this conversation so how 
do you deal with that? Well, a lot of mechanisms

are used and one of them, a primary one, is thought 
control, indoctrination, that's what the phrase

"necessary illusions" comes from it's uh not mine 
it comes from Reinhold Niebuhr who's a leading

theologian, he's called the theologian of the 
establishment, he was the guru for the Kennedy

intellectuals and George Kennan, and so on, 
a major figure in modern intellectual history,

and he pointed out once that the ordinary people 
don't have the capacity, according to him, to become

involved in public affairs, so it's the task of 
what he called the "cool observers", meaning us smart

guys, it's our task to impose "necessary illusions" 
and "emotionally potent oversimplifications" to

keep these poor simpletons on course, and it 
would be kind of unfair to let ordinary people,

to let the democratic process really work. If 
you really let ordinary people make decisions
or you know think about things or whatever, they'd only get in trouble. Uh, it's like letting a
three-year-old cross the street, you know, it's to the interest of the three-year-old that

you constrain them, and similarly it's to 
the interests of the general public that

you marginalize them and ensure that the formal 
political system has not very much substance

because it's only the smart guys, the cool 
observers, who have the capacity

to make the right decisions and those now 
it turns out that the cool observers who are

in a position to make the right decisions are 
those who serve the interests of private power.

Other cool observers are not cool observers 
because they have the wrong decisions,

he didn't bother mentioning that part, uh and 
that's a very typical view, it's not just his view
in fact it's probably the dominant view. So, for example, the book that i co-authored right before

this one is called "Manufacturing Consent" which 
borrows a phrase from Walter Lippmann who is a sort of

dean of American journalists 
and major foreign policy critic

and his view, sort of the same was that you 
have to that's a it's crucial part of democracy

he said is the "manufacture of consent" uh the 
population he referred to as "the bewildered herd"

and he said we have to save ourselves from 
the rage and trampling of the bewildered herd

and since unfortunately you can't do 
it by force you have to do it by other means

The other means would be the manufacture 
of consent. The United States, uh, the public

relations industry in the United States, which goes 
back to the early part of the century, is dedicated

to that, that's a pure business operation ,
and they're dedicated to it, everything from

,you know, advertising to other mechanisms 
of influence and which they openly call and

there are more honest days they openly called 
propaganda and the same is true of much of the

intellectual class. It recognizes, 
the more sophisticated people recognize,
that their job is thought control, and they argue, that it's the right thing

because the bewildered herd will only get into 
trouble if you let them rage on by themselves.

Q: For thought control don't you need, though, to 
have complete control over a system, no outside

information coming in at all. No, not really, 
that's the mistake that dictators usually make.

Dictators are usually much too crude. They 
have a ministry of truth which you know blocks any

wrong information. Actually, even in dictatorships 
you know there's usually quite a lot of give but

they have the capacity at least to control 
everything. Our systems don't work like that at all,

in fact, they're probably much more 
effective because they don't work like that.

They have roughly the same effect but they convey 
a sense of freedom and the sense of freedom is

real like we can do what we're doing. You know, 
you can have a program in Salem which will say

tell the truth about Panama, meanwhile the three tv 
channels will be telling corporate government lies

about Panama, but you're allowed to compete, that's 
what's called a free free market. You know like if

you and i could sit down and decide to open a car 
manufacturing plant and nobody would stop us from

competing with General Motors. Okay, we want to do 
it, that's fine,you know police aren't going to

stop us, that's a free society. The effect will be 
exactly as if the police came in and stopped us.
Now, it's roughly the same in this case you know.
